title: Boots saw sales fall over summer amid 'challenging' conditions on High Street
text:
Boots saw sales fall over the summer amid 'challenging' conditions on the High Street.

Sales at the chemists' chain fell 2.1 per cent in the three months to August 31, with like-for-like pharmacy sales dropping 1 per cent and retail sales dropping 2.7 per cent.

It was hit by 'challenging' conditions on the High Street and less cash from the NHS.

A sign of things to come: Sales at the chemists' chain fell 2.1 per cent in the three months to August 31

The turmoil in the UK was partly blamed for a fall in profits overall at its US parent, Walgreens Boots Alliance.

It has prompted the company to make radical cost cuts, with 200 Boots stores set to be closed and hundreds of jobs axed at its Nottingham headquarters. Boots is also trying to boost sales of beauty products and of drugs online.

Sebastian James, Boots' boss, said: 'I am pleased with the progress that we have made in the re-boot of one of Britain's best-loved retailers. Nevertheless, we are aware that this is a journey and that market headwinds have been strong and look likely to remain so for some time.

'Though we have declined in like-for-like terms this year, I am glad that we have retained share across the board and grown significant share in beauty and pleased with the progress we're making to digitise our pharmacy offer.'

Walgreens said overall revenue for the fourth quarter this year had slightly increased from £26 billion to £26.4 billion.

It brought its full-year sales to £106.4 billion, up from £102.3 billion in 2018. But profits fell from £4.6 billion to £3.5 billion during the period.
